Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ridge-runnel post-storm beach recovery - hydrodynamics, sediment transport and morphodynamics
Award.AbstractNarration: Funds are provided for the project to investigate the hydrodynamics and sediment transport processes associated with migrating ridge and runnel systems. Novel insitu techniques developed from wave flume experiments will be combined with remote sensing methods to quantify sheet flow, suspended sediment transport, and morphodynamic response in a ridge and runnel system in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. Results will be used to test the hypothesis that sheet flow processes dominate ridge and runnel migration, and to develop a comprehensive understanding of the morphologic evolution of these systems from inception through attachment to the beach. This research may lead to improved management of beach erosion and recovery. The project will support a PhD student (with recruitment targeted towards underrepresented minorities) and two undergraduate students. The PIs will construct and train teachers to operate a portable flume for use in three Texas high schools participating in the ?Beach in a Classroom? program. Project results will be incorporated into public outreach activities in Texas and Delaware.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Beaches are the last line of defense between wave-driven forcing and landward infrastructure. Beaches, particularly the berm and dune provide sacrificial sand during storms to dissipate oceanic energy. Eroded sand is carried offshore but is often returned back to the beach face over time meaning that natural beaches have some capacity to recover following a storm event. Understanding beach erosion during storms and subsequent recovery is necessary to validate predictive models. These models are used by researchers, industry, government agencies, and natural resource managers to estimate expected erosion rates and sand movement back to the beach following a storm.

 

The project uses extensive arrays of oceanographic and sediment transport sensors to measures the fluid processes and the sediment response during storm events. Concurrent measurements of the beach change were sampled using global positioning system (GPS) surveying and photogrammetry techniques. Field experiments were conducted in Bethany Beach, DE, USA and Sisal, Yucatan, Mexico. Data were sampled from offshore providing wave conditions in the surf zone and on the beach face.

 

Results from the project showed the strong variations in forcing on the sea bed between storm and non-storm conditions and the importance of wave breaking at the beach face in suspending sediment that could be transported by offshore-directed flows. Measurements showed berm erosion on the order of 1 meter vertically on the order of hours with the onset of a storm. Surprisingly, the berm began to rebuild during storm subsidence. Overall accretion was greater than one meter with the beach becoming steeper than it was prior to the storm. Presently used predictive equations for sediment transport rates were tested but had a wide range of error indicating the need for still improved measurements of these processes during storms. A numerical model for predicting post-storm recovery was validated and showed good skill in reproducing the berm growth and beach steepening during storm subsidence.

 

The project consisted of several broader impact items including: undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral training and advisement, mentoring of a young faculty member; use of portable wave flumes in classes to deliver the “Beach in a Classroom” concept of coastal processes; numerous beach and coastal processes demonstrations for school groups; the coordination and organization of an international workshop; and the development and delivery of a conference series for young coastal scientists and engineers.
